citations.authors: Allen, J. J., & Anderson, C. A.
citations.title: General Aggression Model
citations.synthesis: Defines the cognitive-neuro loop: Person/Situation inputs → Internal state (Affect/Arousal/Cognition) → Appraisal → Outcomes. Foundation for episodic aggression models.
citations.notes: Foundational theoretical framework for understanding aggression as dynamic process

citations.title: Foundation for a general strain theory of crime and delinquency
citations.synthesis: Primary source for GST. Violence as maladaptive response to actual or anticipated negative stimuli when conventional coping is blocked.
citations.notes: Seminal paper establishing General Strain Theory framework

citations.title: Structural and social determinants of inequities in violence risk: A review of indicators
citations.synthesis: Examines how community-level indicators like economic inequality, residential segregation, and infrastructure quality drive disparate violence risks across neighborhoods.
citations.notes: Comprehensive review of structural determinants at community level

citations.title: New directions in social disorganization theory
citations.source: Journal of Research in Crime and Delinquency
citations.synthesis: Defines Collective Efficacy: The combination of social trust and willingness to intervene for common good that suppresses neighborhood violence independently of economic factors.
citations.notes: Important extension of social disorganization theory with collective efficacy concept

citations.title: Horizontal inequalities and nonviolent conflict: A comprehensive review
citations.synthesis: Horizontal Inequalities between identity groups, particularly political exclusion from executive power, are stronger predictors of civil war than economic inequality alone.
citations.notes: Distinguishes political exclusion as primary driver vs economic inequality

citations.title: Association of rising temperatures with increased violence worldwide: A systematic review and meta-analysis
citations.synthesis: Meta-analysis confirms +1°C temperature rise = 1.64% increase in violent events globally. Critically, effect specific to interpersonal violence with zero significant effect on property crimes.
citations.notes: Important specificity: interpersonal violence only, not property crime

citations.title: Alcohol, drugs, and violence: A meta-meta-analysis
citations.synthesis: Large-scale meta-meta-analysis: Substance misuse correlates with violence across clinical and non-clinical populations, with strongest effects for alcohol intoxication.
citations.notes: Highest level of evidence synthesis - meta-meta-analysis

citations.title: The prevalence of adverse childhood experiences among justice-involved youth: A systematic review and meta-analysis
citations.synthesis: Synthesizes finding of 87% ACEs prevalence among justice-involved youth populations, demonstrating developmental trauma as primary pathway to violence.
citations.notes: Striking prevalence rate demonstrating trauma-violence pathway

citations.title: Violence and mental disorders: A structured review
citations.synthesis: Clinical risk audit: Mental illness increases relative risk but absolute violence rates remain low. Co-occurring substance misuse dramatically increases absolute risk.
citations.notes: Important distinction between relative and absolute risk

citations.title: Algorithmic polarization and the amplification of online aggression
citations.synthesis: Empirical evidence for how algorithmic recommendation systems systematically push users toward extreme aggressive content through engagement optimization.
citations.notes: High-impact journal, computational methods for algorithmic analysis

citations.title: Hate speech, information disorder, and conflict
citations.synthesis: Analyzes online 'fun' and meme culture as catalysts for dehumanizing discourse, demonstrating how playful framing facilitates collective aggression.
citations.notes: Important for understanding cultural mechanisms of online hate

citations.title: Colonial legacy and contemporary civil violence: A cross-national analysis
citations.synthesis: Analyzes path-dependent imprints of colonial administrative styles on modern civil violence patterns, demonstrating how historical institutions create durable conflict structures.
citations.notes: Important for understanding institutional persistence and path dependence
